testName: ICT2641 Quiz: Chapter 9 – Making the Business Case

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of a business case
options: B) To justify investment in a proposed change
questions.correctAnswer: B) To justify investment in a proposed change
questions.explanation: The business case provides the justification for why the investment is necessary and what value it will deliver.

questions.text: Which section of the business case outlines the strategic context?
questions.explanation: The Background section typically explains the strategic environment, drivers and context for the change.

questions.text: What does the “do nothing” option represent?
questions.explanation: The “do nothing” (or status quo) option serves as a baseline to compare other options in the business case.

questions.text: Which technique adjusts future cash flows for time value of money?
questions.explanation: Net Present Value (NPV) discounts future cash flows to today’s value to account for time value of money. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

questions.text: What does IRR stand for?
questions.explanation: IRR is the discount rate that makes the NPV of a project zero, representing the expected rate of return. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

questions.text: Which section assesses effects on people, processes, and technology?
questions.explanation: An Impact Assessment section examines how the change will affect people, processes, and technology.

questions.text: What is a key benefit of using DCF techniques?
questions.explanation: Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) techniques such as NPV and IRR incorporate the time value of money.

questions.text: In Agile environments, business cases are:
questions.explanation: In Agile settings business cases may evolve and are less formal/traditional, adapting as the project progresses.

questions.text: Which section outlines financial, resource, and time investments?
questions.explanation: The Costs section details the investments required (financial, resource, time) for the project.

questions.text: What does a positive NPV indicate?
questions.explanation: A positive NPV means the project is expected to generate more value than its cost, so it’s financially viable. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

questions.text: Which of the following is not typically included in a business case?
questions.explanation: While technical architecture may be referenced, business cases focus more on business justification rather than detailed technical design.

questions.text: What is the role of sensitivity analysis in a business case?
options: To assess how changes in assumptions affect outcomes
questions.correctAnswer: To assess how changes in assumptions affect outcomes
questions.explanation: Sensitivity analysis tests how changes in key assumptions (costs, benefits, discount rate) affect project outcomes such as NPV. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

questions.text: Which stakeholder is most likely to approve the business case?
questions.explanation: The Sponsor is typically the person with authority to approve the business case and allocate funding.

questions.text: What does the acronym DCF stand for?
questions.explanation: DCF represents the method of discounting future cash flows in financial appraisal.

questions.text: What is a key limitation of the Payback Period method?
options: It doesn’t consider time value of money
questions.correctAnswer: It doesn’t consider time value of money
questions.explanation: Payback period is simple but ignores the time value of money and cash flows beyond payback.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the “Options Considered” section?
questions.explanation: The Options Considered section shows that multiple alternatives were evaluated, supporting sound decision making.

questions.text: Which of the following is a qualitative benefit?
questions.explanation: Qualitative benefits are non‑financial, such as improved customer satisfaction, whereas others are quantitative.

questions.text: What does a negative NPV suggest?
questions.explanation: A negative NPV means the project is expected to reduce value rather than add it, so it’s not financially viable. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

questions.text: What is the first step in developing a business case?
questions.explanation: Understanding the strategic context sets the foundation for aligning the business case with organisational goals.

questions.text: Which of the following is a financial appraisal technique?
questions.explanation: Cost‐benefit analysis evaluates the monetary costs and benefits of options and is a key technique in business cases.

questions.text: What does the implementation plan include?
questions.explanation: The Implementation Plan details how the proposed change will be delivered, including key timelines, resources and milestones.

questions.text: What is the role of the business analyst in business case development?
questions.explanation: The business analyst leads gathering requirements, analysing options, and presenting the case rather than approving funding or executing the project.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key input to the business case?
questions.explanation: A feasibility study examines the viability of options and supplies important input data for the business case.

questions.text: What does the “Benefits” section describe?
questions.explanation: The Benefits section outlines what value the organisation expects to receive if the proposal is implemented.

questions.text: What is the purpose of the “Executive Summary”?
options: To summarise key points for decision‑makers
questions.correctAnswer: To summarise key points for decision‑makers
questions.explanation: The Executive Summary gives decision‑makers a concise overview of the case—purpose, investment, benefits, risks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a strategic driver for a business case?
questions.explanation: Strategic drivers might include compliance, regulation, market position, sustainability—these drive the need for change.

questions.text: What is the difference between IRR and NPV?
options: IRR is qualitative; NPV is quantitative
IRR is a percentage; NPV is a currency value
IRR is used for Agile; NPV for Waterfall
IRR ignores time value; NPV includes it
questions.correctAnswer: IRR is a percentage; NPV is a currency value
questions.explanation: NPV yields a dollar difference in present value; IRR yields a percentage rate of return. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

questions.text: What does “do minimum” option represent?
questions.explanation: The “do minimum” option represents the least‑cost/least‑change alternative that still addresses the issue, used for comparison.

questions.text: What is the role of assumptions in a business case?
options: To clarify the basis of projections
questions.correctAnswer: To clarify the basis of projections
questions.explanation: Assumptions document the basis of the business case’s financial and non‑financial forecasts, making them transparent.

questions.text: Which financial appraisal method is most sensitive to changes in discount rate assumptions?
questions.explanation: NPV is sensitive to the discount rate because it directly affects the present value of future cash flows. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

questions.text: In a business case, what does the term “non‑financial disbenefit” refer to?
options: A cost not captured in the budget
questions.explanation: A non‑financial disbenefit is a disadvantage or negative outcome that cannot easily be quantified financially—e.g., reduced flexibility.

questions.text: What is the strategic risk of excluding the “do nothing” option?
questions.explanation: Without the status quo option, it’s hard to compare alternatives fairly and understand incremental value.

questions.text: Which of the following is a valid reason to reject a project with a positive NPV?
questions.explanation: Even with good financials, if the project does not align with organisational strategy, it may be rejected.

questions.text: Which stakeholder is most likely to challenge assumptions in the financial model?
questions.explanation: A finance analyst often scrutinises assumptions, discount rates and cash flows to validate financial credibility.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key ethical consideration in business case development?
questions.explanation: Ethics requires that assumptions and data are presented clearly and honestly, not manipulated for undue advantage.

questions.text: What is the role of scenario planning in business case analysis?
questions.explanation: Scenario planning allows the business case to assess how outcomes might vary under different conditions and risks.

questions.text: Which metric best captures the efficiency of capital investment?
questions.explanation: IRR captures the rate of return on an investment and thus reflects efficiency of capital employed. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

questions.text: What does a high sensitivity to cost assumptions indicate?
questions.explanation: If the outcome changes dramatically when cost assumptions shift, the project is risky and requires careful review.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a post‑implementation review?
options: To assess actual vs projected benefits
questions.correctAnswer: To assess actual vs projected benefits
questions.explanation: A post‑implementation review compares what was delivered and what benefit realised against the business case.

questions.text: Which of the following undermines the credibility of a business case?
questions.explanation: If stakeholders were not involved, assumptions and outcomes may be viewed as ungrounded and reduce trust.

questions.text: What is the role of governance frameworks in business case approval?
questions.explanation: Governance provides structure around how business cases are reviewed, approved and monitored.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the “do minimum” option?
questions.explanation: The “do minimum” represents the minimum viable change option that still addresses the problem but at lowest cost/risk.
